answers.body_markdown:
So, I'm new to compose and I was trying to make the exact same thing.
The compiler didn't let me inject the AppViewModel as a dependency to the ChildViewModel, so I ended up doing the following:

 1. Created a data class (AppStateHolder) to store loading bool value.
 2. At AppViewModel I inject AppStateHolder as dependency.
 3. Added to appmodule the hilt reference generator with @Singleton and @Provides annotation.
 4. I inject at ChildViewModel reference to AppStateHolder.
 5. AppStateHolder has a mutable state for the isLoading boolean.
 5. At AppViewModel init block I collect the appStateHolder values and update the mutable state accordingly.
 6. When necessary at ChildViewModel I update AppStateHolder values.
 
So you can inject AppStateHolder, update its values, and when you make this, AppViewModel will be notified and updates its own state.
The setback is, if you havea lot of ui state variables at AppViewModel you have to replicate them at AppStateHolder and always observe them at AppViewModel.

I know it's not the best option, but I will be looking for other ways or till someone comes with a better solution.
answers.title: Android Hilt. Is it possible to Inject one ViewModel into another?
answers.body:
So, I'm new to compose and I was trying to make the exact same thing. The compiler didn't let me inject the AppViewModel as a dependency to the ChildViewModel, so I ended up doing the following:

  1. Created a data class (AppStateHolder) to store loading bool value.
  2. At AppViewModel I inject AppStateHolder as dependency.
  3. Added to appmodule the hilt reference generator with @Singleton and @Provides annotation.
  4. I inject at ChildViewModel reference to AppStateHolder.
  5. AppStateHolder has a mutable state for the isLoading boolean.
  6. At AppViewModel init block I collect the appStateHolder values and update the mutable state accordingly.
  7. When necessary at ChildViewModel I update AppStateHolder values.

So you can inject AppStateHolder, update its values, and when you make this, AppViewModel will be notified and updates its own state. The setback is, if you havea lot of ui state variables at AppViewModel you have to replicate them at AppStateHolder and always observe them at AppViewModel.

I know it's not the best option, but I will be looking for other ways or till someone comes with a better solution.

answers.title: Android Hilt. Is it possible to Inject one ViewModel into another?
answers.body:
I had similar issue, I needed session view model, indicating that I needed it injected everywhere, in almost all view models. So, there was eg. LoginViewModel created like this:

@HiltViewModel
class LoginViewModel @Inject constructor(
    private val loginRepository: LoginRepository,
    private val sessionViewModel: SessionViewModel,
) : BaseViewModel<LoginContract.Event, LoginContract.State, LoginContract.Effect>() {
    ...

and then I needed a bit of a hack for SessionViewModel:

/** Note: not @HiltViewModel since it is not possible to inject HiltViewModel into another one.
 * So, this is left to be a viewModel, but it is injected via [AppModule.provideSessionViewModel()]
 */
class SessionViewModel @Inject constructor() :
    BaseViewModel<SessionContract.Event, SessionContract.State, SessionContract.Effect>() {
    ...

@Singleton
@Provides
fun provideSessionViewModel() : SessionViewModel {
   return SessionViewModel()
}

Then, it can be injected on UI if needed there:

@Inject
lateinit var sessionViewModel: SessionViewModel

comments.body_markdown:
Thank you,


When a checked exception is thrown, only callers who can handle it properly should catch it with a try/catch.

A runtime exception, should not be caught in the program. If you catch it, you run the risk that a bug in the code will be hidden from view at runtime.

Is my understanding right?

If you catch it, you run the risk that a bug in the code will be hidden from view at runtime.  Is my understanding right?

comments.body_markdown: @miaosun: Not necessarily - you certainly *can* catch RuntimeExceptions, and *sometimes* that's appropriate... but it's less common.
comments.body: @miaosun: Not necessarily - you certainly can catch RuntimeExceptions, and sometimes that's appropriate... but it's less common.

answers.body_markdown:
> I don't know why we need throws keywords

In this case, you don't - because `IllegalArgumentException` extends `RuntimeException`. It's therefore not a *checked exception*, and doesn't need to be declared in a method that throws it.

See the [Java tutorial](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/essential/exceptions/catchOrDeclare.html) for more details on when you need to use a `throws` declaration.

items.body:
I created a prototype of a small rover with a raspberry, using python I created a script that allows me to move it simply by pressing a few keys on the keyboard.

The script essentially waits for a key to be pressed to "command" the rover motors, the code works through a terminal shell, now what I would like is to create a web UI or an Android app that allows me to command the rover without using a shell.

The source code is something like that:

#!/usr/bin/env python
#!/bin/bash
import RPi.GPIO as GPIO
from time import sleep

print("\n")
print("A-forward S-backward L-left turn R-right turn  l-low m-medium h-high e-exit")
print("\n")

a=11
b=15
c=16
d=18

def init():    
    GPIO.setmode(GPIO.BCM)
    GPIO.setup(a, GPIO.OUT)
    GPIO.setup(b, GPIO.OUT)
    GPIO.setup(c, GPIO.OUT)
    GPIO.setup(d, GPIO.OUT)
    p=GPIO.PWM(d,1000)
    p.start(25)

def forward():
    init()
    //MORE STUFF

def reverse():
    init()
    //MORE STUFF

def left_turn():
    init()
    //MORE STUFF

def right_turn():
    init()
    //MORE STUFF

while(1):

    x=input()
    if x=='w':
        print("forward")
        forward()
        x='z'

    elif x=='s':
        print("backward")
        reverse()
        x='z'

    elif x=='a':
        print("left")
        left_turn()
        x='z'

    elif x=='d':
        print("right")
        right_turn()
        x='z'

    elif x=='e':
        GPIO.cleanup()
        break

    else:
        print("<<<  wrong data  >>>")
        print("please enter the defined data to continue.....")

How can I create a graphical interface (basically formed by 4 buttons that will represent the directions) that can interact with a python script? Is it possible to continue to use a script as a basis for moving my rover or should I implement a different solution?

More than a solution I'm interested in understanding if I can use the base script and if I can hook it to a UI.

items.body:
I have Product that contains Portfolios and each Portfolio have InvestmentAllocation. When I add a new Product with portfolios with investment allocation, all the data is stored in the database. When I try to edit existing products and edit its portfolios and investment allocations, all the data is being updated successfully. But when I update existing product and try to add a new portfolio to it with investment allocation,I am getting the following error:

Caused by: java.sql.SQLException: Cannot insert the value NULL into column 'PortfolioKey', table 'productsdb.dbo.InvestmentAllocation'; column does not allow nulls. INSERT fails.

I am using @PostPersist annotation to fill the null values with the captured ids. The problem is that on update I cannot add new portfolio with new investment allocation. When I remove the investment allocation from the portfolio I am able to add the new portfolio to the existing product. I assume that when we have existing product and try to add new portfolio with new investment, the @PostPersist annotation is ignored inside the class Portfolio.

@Table(name = "Product")
public class Product extends MutableEntity {

    private static final long serialVersionUID = 8675881197953603577L;

    @Column(name = "ClientKey")
    private Long clientId;

    @Column(name = "Administrator")
    private String administrator;

    @OneToMany(
            fetch = FetchType.LAZY,
            cascade = {CascadeType.ALL},
            orphanRemoval = true
    )
    @JoinColumn(
            name = "ProductKey",
            nullable = false,
            insertable = false,
            updatable = false
    )
    @Cascade({org.hibernate.annotations.CascadeType.ALL})
    private Set<Portfolio> portfolios;

    @PostPersist
    protected void postPersist() {
        Iterator var1;
        if (this.portfolios != null) {
            var1 = this.portfolios.iterator();

            while (var1.hasNext()) {
                Portfolio portfolio = (Portfolio) var1.next();
                if (portfolio.getProductId() == null) {
                    portfolio.setProductId(this.getId());
                }
            }
        }
    }
}

@Table(name = "Portfolio")
public class Portfolio extends MutableEntity {

    private static final long serialVersionUID = -6668016124280143515L;

    @Column(name = "ProductKey")
    private Long productId;

    @Column(name = "Name")
    private String name;

    @Column(name = "Amount")

    @OneToOne(fetch = FetchType.EAGER, cascade = CascadeType.ALL, mappedBy = "genericScenarioPortfolio")
    private InvestmentAllocation investmentAllocation;

    @PostPersist

        if (this.investmentAllocation != null) {
            if (this.investmentAllocation.getPortfolioId() == null) {

}

    @OneToOne(fetch = FetchType.EAGER, cascade = CascadeType.ALL)

}

Here is my save functionality:

 @Transactional
    public SaveProductPayload saveProduct(SaveProductInput input, DataFetchingEnvironment env) {
        Product source = productDTOMapper.toProduct(input);
        Long id = source.getId();
        Product target = new Product();
        if (id != null) {
            target = productRepository.findById(id).orElseThrow(()
                    -> new ProductNotFoundException(String.format("No entity found for id %s.", id)));
        }
        target = productDTOMapper.overlay(source, target);

        PortfolioMergeFactory.merge(target, portfolioDTOMapper.toPortfolios(input.getPortfolios()));
        
        Product scenarioProduct = productRepository.save(target);
        return new SaveProductPayload(input.getClientMutationId());
    }

public class PortfolioMergeFactory {
    private PortfolioMergeFactory() {
    }

    public static void merge(Product target, Collection<Portfolio> source) {
        werePortfoliosAdded(target, source);
        werePortfoliosUpdated(target, source);
        werePortfoliosRemoved(target, source);
    }

    private static void werePortfoliosAdded(Product target, Collection<Portfolio> source) {
        if (source != null) {
            if (target.getPortfolios() == null) {
                target.setPortfolios(new HashSet<>());
            }
            Set<Portfolio> copy = Sets.newHashSet(target.getGenericPortfolios());
            for (Portfolio portfolio : source) {
                if (copy.stream().noneMatch(e -> e.getName().equals(portfolio.getName()))) {
                    Portfolio newPortfolio = new Portfolio();
                    newPortfolio.setProductId(target.getId());
                    newPortfolio.setName(portfolio.getName());
                    newPortfolio.setAmount(portfolio.getAmount());
                    newPortfolio.setInvestmentAllocation(portfolio.getInvestmentAllocation());
                    target.getGenericPortfolios().add(newPortfolio);
                }
            }
        }
    }

    private static void werePortfoliosUpdated(Product target, Collection<Portfolio> sourceList) {
        if (target.getPortfolios() != null && sourceList != null) {

            for (Portfolio source : sourceList) {
                Portfolio persisted = target.getPortfolios().stream().filter((e) -> {
                    return e.getId() != null && e.getName() != null && e.getName().equals(source.getName());
                }).findFirst().orElse(null);
                if (persisted != null) {
                    persisted.setProductId(target.getId());
                    persisted.setName(source.getName());
                    persisted.setAmount(source.getAmount());
                    if (source.getInvestmentAllocation() != null) {
                        source.getInvestmentAllocation().setPortfolioId(persisted.getId());
                    }
                    persisted.setInvestmentAllocation(source.getInvestmentAllocation());
                }
            }
        }
    }

    private static void werePortfoliosRemoved(Product target, Collection<Portfolio> source) {
        if (target.getPortfolios() != null && source != null) {
            target.getPortfolios().removeIf(thisObject -> source.stream()
                    .noneMatch(otherObject -> otherObject.getName().equals(thisObject.getName())));

        } else if (target.getPortfolios() != null) {
            for (Portfolio portfolio : new ArrayList<>(target.getPortfolios())) {
                target.getPortfolios().remove(portfolio);
            }
        }
    }
}

items.title: Java Double Stream sort in reverse order
items.body:
I am learning about Java Streams and I have created some functions to test and I am struggling to find a way to sort in reverse order

Here is the code:

public class StreamCreator {

    public List<Fruit> getMixedFruitList() {
        return Arrays.asList(
                new Fruit(true),
                new Orange(),
                new BloodOrange(),
                new BloodOrange(),
                new BloodOrange(),
                new Orange(),
                new Fruit(),
                new Mango(),
                new Mango(),
                new Mango(),
                new BloodOrange()
        );
    }

    public Stream<Fruit> getFruitStream() {
        return getMixedFruitList().stream();
    }

    public Stream<Fruit> getParallelFruitStream() {
        return getMixedFruitList().parallelStream(); // Works
        //return getMixedFruitList().stream().parallel(); //Works
    }

    public Stream<String> getStringStream() {
        return Stream.of("A", "h", "c", "z", "Z", "b", "H", "M", "o", "9", "3", "8", "2", "1");
    }

    public IntStream getIntStreamByRange(int start, int end, boolean closed) {
        return (closed) ?
                IntStream.rangeClosed(start, end) :
                IntStream.range(start, end);
    }

    public LongStream getLongStreamByRange(long start, long end, boolean closed) {
        return (closed) ?
                LongStream.rangeClosed(start, end) :
                LongStream.range(start, end);
    }

    public DoubleStream getDoubleStream() {
        return DoubleStream.of(1.3, 98.7, 48.46, 68.47, 2.5, 6.7, 4.6, 9.2, 100.5, 4.6, 0.48, 3.0);
    }


}

public static void intermediateOperatorsEg2() {
        streamCreator
                .getDoubleStream()
                .sorted()
                .boxed()
                .collect(Collectors.toList())
                .forEach(sorted -> System.out.print(sorted + ", "));

        streamCreator
                .getDoubleStream()
                .sorted(Comparator.reverseOrder())

                .boxed()
                .collect(Collectors.toList());
    }

public static void main(String[] args) {
        //filterExample();
        //intermediateOperatorsEg1();
        intermediateOperatorsEg2();
    }

When I do Comparator.reverseOrder() I get the following error:

'sorted()' in 'java.util.stream.DoubleStream' cannot be applied to '(java.util.Comparator<T>)'

Then if I try:

.sorted(Comparator.comparingDouble(Double::valueOf))

It doesn't work, If the stream is passing down each double value, what is the best way to reverse this ?

answers.body_markdown:
You could read the JSONObject into a java string, and call String.toLowerCase on it and store it back into a JSONObject. This will turn the entire case of the string to lower case, so you will have to account for that elsewhere in your logic. After that, you then would just have to do a get call on "inputhivetable". 

By no means is it a pretty solution, but it is a potential work around if there is absolutely no other way for you to handle what you're returning as your JSON input.
answers.title: How to ignore case when searching a JSON Object
answers.body:
You could read the JSONObject into a java string, and call String.toLowerCase on it and store it back into a JSONObject. This will turn the entire case of the string to lower case, so you will have to account for that elsewhere in your logic. After that, you then would just have to do a get call on "inputhivetable".

By no means is it a pretty solution, but it is a potential work around if there is absolutely no other way for you to handle what you're returning as your JSON input.

answers.body_markdown:
Given that case-insensitivity can be achieved with TreeMap (i.e. via `String.CASE_INSENSITIVE_ORDER` comparator), you can probably do the following:

1. Implement your own `MyJSONObject` extending `TreeMap` where its methods will be just calling static methods of `JSONObject` with the same signatures and all required interfaces as in `JSONObject`. In default constructor write `super(String.CASE_INSENSITIVE_ORDER)`

2. Implement `ContainerFactory` interface where `createObjectContainer` will return new instance of `MyJSONObject` (and `createArrayContainer` will just return new `JSONArray`).

3. To run it with new container `MyContainerFactory`:

         StringReader in = new StringReader(yourJSONString);                    
         JSONParser parser = new JSONParser();      
         parser.parse(in, yourContainerFactory)

answers.title: How to ignore case when searching a JSON Object
answers.body:
If you have to perform this case-insensitive lookup many times, I'd just write a method to do that lookup:

public Object getIgnoreCase(JSONObject jobj, String key) {

    Iterator<String> iter = jobj.keySet().iterator();
    while (iter.hasNext()) {
        String key1 = iter.next();
        if (key1.equalsIgnoreCase(key)) {
            return jobj.get(key1);
        }
    }

    return null;

}

answers.body_markdown:
# This is allowed in Java 16+

This is **no longer forbidden starting with Java 16** (and the later LTS release Java 17) thanks to [JEP 395][1] relaxing the rules on some static types inside inner classes.

The new phrasing in [§8.1.3. Inner Classes and Enclosing Instances][2] is (emphsis mine):

> All of the rules that apply to nested classes apply to inner classes. In particular, **an inner class may declare** and inherit **static members** (§8.2), and declare `static` initializers (§8.7), even though the inner class itself is not `static`.

[This answer explains the change][3] in more detail.

# Before Java 16 it was forbidden:

`enum` types that are defined as nested types are always implicitly `static` (see [JLS §8.9. Enums][4]):

> A nested enum type is implicitly `static`.

You can't have a static nested type inside a non-static one (a.k.a an "inner class", see [JLS §8.1.3. Inner Classes and Enclosing Instances][5]):

> It is a compile-time error if an inner class declares a member that is explicitly or implicitly static, unless the member is a constant variable

Therefore you can't have an `enum` inner type inside a non-static nested type.


  [1]: https://openjdk.org/jeps/395
  [2]: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se17/html/jls-8.html#jls-8.1.3
  [3]: https://stackoverflow.com/a/62807591/40342
  [4]: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se11/html/jls-8.html#jls-8.9
  [5]: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se11/html/jls-8.html#jls-8.1.3
answers.title: Why can't I create an enum in an inner class in Java?
answers.body:
This is allowed in Java 16+

This is no longer forbidden starting with Java 16 (and the later LTS release Java 17) thanks to JEP 395 relaxing the rules on some static types inside inner classes.

The new phrasing in §8.1.3. Inner Classes and Enclosing Instances is (emphsis mine):

All of the rules that apply to nested classes apply to inner classes. In particular, an inner class may declare and inherit static members (§8.2), and declare static initializers (§8.7), even though the inner class itself is not static.

This answer explains the change in more detail.

Before Java 16 it was forbidden:

enum types that are defined as nested types are always implicitly static (see JLS §8.9. Enums):

A nested enum type is implicitly static.

You can't have a static nested type inside a non-static one (a.k.a an "inner class", see JLS §8.1.3. Inner Classes and Enclosing Instances):

It is a compile-time error if an inner class declares a member that is explicitly or implicitly static, unless the member is a constant variable

Therefore you can't have an enum inner type inside a non-static nested type.

answers.title: Why can't I create an enum in an inner class in Java?
answers.body:
If you declared an enum like this:

enum Suit {SPADES, HEARTS, CLUBS, DIAMONDS}

The Java compiler would synthetically generate the following class for you:

final class Suit extends java.lang.Enum<Suit> {
  public static final Suit SPADES;
  public static final Suit HEARTS;
  public static final Suit CLUBS;
  public static final Suit DIAMONDS;
  private static final Suit[] $VALUES;
  public static Suit[] values();
  public static Suit valueOf(java.lang.String);
  private Suit();
}

There is no intention to create other instances of this class other than those static fields already defined in it (as you could infer from its private constructor), but most importantly, and as mentioned in the accepted answer, a inner class cannot have static members (JLS §8.1.3. Inner Classes and Enclosing Instances), and since the enum synthetic class does, it makes it unacceptable as inner class.

comments.body_markdown: Well, storing the instance of the activity in the SignalingService might cause context leak. IMO it would be a little more efficient to pass the listener into SignalingService via setter (not constructor). This way, you can use utilize fragment's lifecycle callback to set fragment as a listener, and remove itself (passing null into listener, for instance) as a listener when fragment is no longer available (after onDestroyView() for instance).

answers.body_markdown: When creating instance of `SignallerService` you're passing activity's instance into constructor, so it's used as a listener, and get's all the callbacks. You should either propagate callback to the Fragment from the activity (from within the activity's `onPublishMessage` search the instance of the fragment and call it's callback method manually), or register Fragment's instance as a listener (pass it into `SignallerService` constructor). In your current implementation, your service knows only about activity (as it's the only listener, who called the constructor and passed itself as listener for future events)

items.title: Interface method is not invoked on all implementations
items.body:
I have an interface that is like so:

public interface ISignaller {
    void onPublishMessage(String message);
}
public interface ISignaller2 {
    void onPublishMessage(String message);
}

And a service that uses this ISignaller

public class SignallerService {
    ISignalR listener;
    
    public SignallerService(ISignalR listener) {
        this.listener = listener;
    }
    
    public void start() {
        // ... some method here
        var someVar = someMethod();
        if (someVar) {
            listener.onPublishMessage("THIS IS CALLED");
        }
    }
}

public class MainActivity extends BaseActivity implements ISignaller
{
    SignallerService ss = new SignallerService(this);
    
    public void start() {
        ss.start();
    }

    public void setPublisher(ISignaller2 publisher) {
        this.publisher = publisher;
    }
    
    // THIS GETS CALLED
    @Override
    public void onPublishMessage(String message) {
        this.publisher.onPublishMessage(message);
    }
}

public class FirstFragment extends Fragment implements ISignaller {

    // THIS IS NOT CALLED
    @Override
    public void onPublishMessage(String message) {
        Log.i("TAG", message);
    }
    
    MainActivity mMainActivity = (MainActivity)getActivity();
    mMainActivity.setPublisher(this);
    mMainActivity.start();
}

Why is it that the override onPublishMesesage in MainActivity gets called but not in the FirstFragment?

answers.title: How to add Swagger Ui to spring 3 on java 19 maven project
answers.body:
I have a different configuration that works with Spring Boot 3.

My dependencies are:

        <dependency>
            <groupId>io.springfox</groupId>
            <artifactId>springfox-boot-starter</artifactId>
            <version>3.0.0</version>
        </dependency>

        <dependency>
            <groupId>io.springfox</groupId>
            <artifactId>springfox-swagger-ui</artifactId>
            <version>2.9.2</version>
        </dependency>

and in the Spring Boot configuration class I added

    @Bean
    public Docket api() {
        return new Docket(DocumentationType.SWAGGER_2)
                .select()
                .apis(RequestHandlerSelectors.any())
                .paths(PathSelectors.any())
                .build();
    }

Maybe this will be helpful.
